title: Contributing to bbouretro
text: outlines propose change bbouretro.

title: Contributing to bbouretro
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to bbouretro
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Contributing to bbouretro
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("", fork = TRUE). Install development dependences devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. Begin commit merge messages - indicate user facing changes included NEWS.md. use fledge automatically generate NEWS.md file.

title: Contributing to bbouretro
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to bbouretro
text: Please note bbouretro project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Getting help with bbouretro
text: opening new issue, sure search issues pull requests make sure bug hasn’t reported /already fixed development version. default, search pre-populated :issue :open. can edit qualifiers (e.g. :pr, :closed) needed. example, ’d simply remove :open search issues repo, open closed.

title: Getting help with bbouretro
text: Start making minimal reproducible example using reprex package. haven’t heard used reprex , ’re treat! Seriously, reprex make R-question-asking endeavors easier (pretty insane ROI five ten minutes ’ll take learn ’s ). additional reprex pointers, check Get help! section tidyverse site.

title: Methods used in `bbouretro` for Estimating Survival, Recruitment, and Population Growth
text: bbr_survival() function uses staggered entry Kaplan-Meier method. staggered entry Kaplan-Meier, uses discrete time steps, defined algebraically (Pollock et al. 1989). probability surviving ith time step (usually month) given equation \hat{S}_{} = 1 - \frac{d_{}}{r_{}} d_{} number mortalities period r_{} number collared individuals start period. estimated survival arbitrary time period t (usually year) given \hat{S}(t) = \prod_{=1}(\hat{S}_{,t}) S survival ith time step tth period. Standard error estimated using Greenwood’s formula (Cox Oakes 1984). SE(\hat{S}(t)) = \sqrt{[\hat{S}(t)]^2 \sum \frac{d_{}}{r_{}(r_{} - d_{})}} Cox Oakes (1984) propose simple binomial variance formula “better tails distribution” (Pollock et al. 1989). SE(\hat{S}(t)) = \sqrt{ \frac{[\hat{S}(t)]^2 - [1-\hat{S}(t)]}{r(t)}} Logit-based confidence limits estimated using Wald method. details Kaplan-Meier approach applied boreal caribou studies given vignette("previous-methods").

title: Methods used in `bbouretro` for Estimating Survival, Recruitment, and Population Growth
text: bbr_recruitment() function estimates recruitment using following method. Estimation recruitment follows methods DeCesare et al. (2012). age ratio, X, commonly estimated number calves, n{_j}, per adult female, n_{af}, observed end measured year, X = \frac{n_j}{n_{af}} X \cdot sex\_ratio estimates number female calves (n_{jf}) per adult female. Recruitment estimated using equation accounts recruitment calves yearling/adult age class end caribou year. R_{RM} = \frac{X \cdot sex\_ratio}{1 + X \cdot sex\_ratio} Variance estimated using bootstrap approach binomial method. bootstrap approach randomly resamples groups 1000 iterations create 1000 estimates calf cow ratio recruitment. Percentile-based 95% confidence limits estimated 1000 estimates. binomial method, variance estimated (R_m \cdot (1 - R_{rm})/n) n number adult females sampled yearly survey. assumed survival recruitment independently distributed logit scale therefore bounding value 0 1. bootstrap method recommended robust approach obtain variance estimates (Manly 1997).

title: Methods used in `bbouretro` for Estimating Survival, Recruitment, and Population Growth
text: bbr_growth() function uses basic Hatter-Bergerud method (Hatter Bergerud 1991). basic Hatter-Bergerud equation used estimate \lambda given . \lambda = \frac{(S)}{(1 - R)} standard errors estimates survival recruitment used create simulated distributions S R derive distribution \lambda based simulated values. assumed survival recruitment distributed logit scale therefore bounding value 0 1. One thousand simulations conducted. Percentile-based confidence limits derived. Also, proportion simulations \lambda greater 1 tabulated provide p-value hypothesis test (Ho: \lambda >= 1, Ha: \lambda < 1). Output summaries also include mean values simulated S, R, well mean median \lambda values simulation. Users can generate plots simulated lambda values using bbr_plot_growth_distributions() yearly estimates using bbr_plot_growth().

title: Traditional Methods for Estimating Survival, Recruitment, and Population Growth
text: Heisey Fuller (1985) method generalization basic approach Mayfield (1961) Trent Rongstad (1974) determine unbiased estimates cause-specific mortality rates. Heisey Fuller (1985) also developed computer program MICROMORT perform calculations. Heisey Fuller (1985) method can described following equations subscript \ (= 1, 2, ..., ) indicates ith interval considered. maximum likelihood estimate survival ith interval (\hat{s}_i) given following equation x_i total number transmitter days (number collar animals multiplied number days) y_i total number deaths \hat{s}_i = \frac{x_i - y_i}{x_i} L_i length days interval estimated survival rate (\hat{S}_i) ith interval \hat{S}_{} = \hat{s}_{}^{L_{}}  total survival rate, S^{*}, , , intervals simply product \hat{S}_{}’s \hat{S}^{*} = \prod_{=1}^{}{\hat{S}_{}} standard error calculated using Taylor series approximation method. sampling distribution \hat{S}^{*} quite skewed therefore 95% Wald confidence interval (Millar 2011) calculated log scale (back-transformed) \log(\hat{S}^*) \pm 1.96 \ \hat{S}^{*-1} \ \text{SE}(\hat{S}^{*}) nonparametric staggered entry Kaplan-Meier, uses discrete time steps, defined algebraically (Pollock et al. 1989). probability surviving ith timestep given equation \hat{S}_i = 1 - \frac{d_i}{r_i} d_i number mortalities period r_i number collared individuals start period. estimated survival arbitrary time period t given \hat{S}(t) = \prod_{=1}{(\hat{S}_{,t})}  \hat{S}_{,t} survival ith timestep tth period. One method estimate standard error (Cox Oakes 1984) uses Greenwood’s formula \text{SE}(\hat{S}(t)) = \sqrt{[\hat{S}(t)]^2 \sum{\frac{d_{}}{r_{}(r_{} - d_{})}}} However also propose simpler alternative estimate “better tails distribution” (Pollock et al. 1989) SE(\hat{S}(t)) = \sqrt{ \frac{[\hat{S}(t)]^2 - [1 - \hat{S}(t)]}{r(t)}} Although Pollock et al. (1989) proposed calculating 95% Wald confidence intervals (Millar 2011) formulation can result lower confidence limits zero upper confidence limits one using standard equation \hat{S}(t) \pm 1.96 \ \text{SE} (\hat{S}(t))  Confidence intervals also computed using bootstrapping 1,000 (McLoughlin et al. 2003) 10,000 replicates (Hervieux et al. 2013). account censoring DeCesare et al. (2012) estimated female survival nonparametric methods “adjusted input annual sample sizes animals survival events produce equivalent mean variance estimates using binomial variance estimator (Morris Doak 2002)” (DeCesare et al. 2012). less used methods like Skalski staggered entry equation (Skalski, Ryding, Millspaugh 2005) known fate binomial model program MARK. known fate model provides similar estimate Kaplan-Meier estimator constrained estimate yearly survival product monthly survival rates. advantage known fate approach allows comparison alternative models , example, constant survival vs yearly /monthly variation. well Heisey Fuller method, Edmonds (1988) also used method described Gasaway et al. (1983) provide estimates confidence intervals.

title: Traditional Methods for Estimating Survival, Recruitment, and Population Growth
text: mean ratio, \hat{R}, can calculated , \bar{y}, mean number calves , \bar{c}, mean number cows (Cochran 1977; Thompson 1992; Krebs 1999) \hat{R} = \frac{\bar{y}}{\bar{c}}  Recruitment rates adjusted DeCesare et al. (2012) provide estimate recruitment assumes calves surveyed March surveys recruited adults. DeCesare et al. (2012) argued uncorrected calf-cow ratios account recruits year end therefore provide overoptimistic estimate recruitment subsequent population trend. equation derived DeCesare et al. (2012), age ratio, X, commonly estimated number calves, n_{j}, per adult female, n_{af}, observed end measured year, X = \frac{n_{j}}{n_{af}}   \frac{X}{2} = \frac{n_{jf}}{n_{af}} X/2 estimates number female calves (n_{jf}) per adult female assuming 50:50 sex ratio, proper adjustments X/2 calves/(calves + adults) ratio necessary according R_{RM} = \frac{n_{jf}}{n_{f}} = \frac{ \frac{X}{2} }{1 + \frac{X}{2}} n_{f} = n_{jf} + n_{af}, total number females age classes, including calves, counted end measurement year. standard error R defined ratio (x/y) given SE(\hat{R}) = \frac{\sqrt{1-f}}{\sqrt{n}y} \sqrt{\frac{(1-f)(\sum{x^{2}-2\hat{R}} \sum{xy+\hat{R}^{2}\sum{y^{2}}})}{n-1}} f sampling fraction n/N, n sample size, N sum sample sizes, \bar{y} observed mean Y measurement (denominator ratio) (Cochran 1977; Thompson 1992; Krebs 1999). Bootstrapping used generate confidence intervals using 1,000 (McLoughlin et al. 2003) 10,000 replicates (Hervieux et al. 2013, 2014). binomial distribution used Rettie Messier (1998).

title: Traditional Methods for Estimating Survival, Recruitment, and Population Growth
text: three main methods used calculating, \lambda, population growth original recruitment-mortality R/M formula described Hatter Bergerud (1991) using raw calf cow ratios R; adjusted recruitment R_{RM} formula DeCesare et al. (2012) Lefkovich matrix model (Fryxell et al. 2020) original recruitment-mortality formula Hatter Bergerud (1991) \lambda = \frac{S}{1-R} adjusted recruitment rate DeCesare et al. (2012) provide better estimate \lambda using uncorrected calf-cow ratios spring surveys (discussed recruitment section). Lefkovich matrix (Fryxell et al. 2020) estimates lambda based maximum eigenvalue Lefkovich matrix stage-based survival birth rates. matrix-based population viability analysis (PVA) model used population-wide estimate annual survival adult yearling females (S) successful offspring recruitment (S \times B, B birth rate female offspring) study area fill elements Lefkovich matrix (L) B_{j} offspring recruitment rate stemming age class j, S_{j} annual survival rate age class j, j=0,1 new-born calves, yearlings, adults (Fryxell et al. 2020). L = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 0 & S_1 \times B_1 & S_a \times B_a \\ S_0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & S_1 & S_a \end{array} \right] DeCesare et al. (2012) also considered stage-based matrix models provides discussion matrix models relate standard S/(1-R) equation. Confidence intervals population growth calculated simulation. One way Monte Carlo simulations randomly drawing annual survival recruitment distributions (Rettie Messier 1998; Hervieux et al. 2013, 2014) using programs like Excel’s MATLAB Poptools. Another method bootstrapping (McLoughlin et al. 2003).

code: @Manual{,   title = {bbouretro: Traditional Survival, Recruitment and Population Growth Methods},   author = {John Boulanger and Ayla Pearson and Joe Thorley},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://poissonconsulting.github.io/bbouretro/}, }

title: Traditional Survival, Recruitment and Population Growth Methods
text: goal bbouretro provide ability calculate survival, recruitment population growth using traditional methods.

title: Traditional Survival, Recruitment and Population Growth Methods
text: install latest version GitHub

title: Traditional Survival, Recruitment and Population Growth Methods
code: set.seed(101)  library(bbouretro) library(bboudata) #>  #> Attaching package: 'bboudata' #> The following object is masked from 'package:bbouretro': #>  #>     licensing_md  # generate recruitment estimate for each year recruitment_est <-   bbr_recruitment(     bboudata::bbourecruit_c,     adult_female_proportion = 0.65,     sex_ratio = 0.5,     variance = "bootstrap"   ) bbr_plot_recruitment(recruitment_est) # generate survival estimate for each year survival_est <-   bbr_survival(     bboudata::bbousurv_c,     include_uncertain_morts = TRUE,     variance = "greenwood"   ) bbr_plot_survival(survival_est) # calculate lambda now that both recruitment and survival have been calculated growth_est <- bbr_growth(survival_est, recruitment_est) summary <- bbr_growth_summarize(growth_est) summary #> # A tibble: 9 × 13 #>   PopulationName CaribouYear     S     R estimate     se  lower  upper prop_lgt1 #>   <chr>                <int> <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1 C                     2004 0.867 0.096    0.959  0.115  0.636  1.08      0.323 #> 2 C                     2005 0.832 0.08     0.904  0.105  0.633  1.03      0.093 #> 3 C                     2006 1     0.068    1.07  NA     NA     NA        NA     #> 4 C                     2007 0.458 0.059    0.487  0.128  0.262  0.766     0     #> 5 C                     2008 0.941 0.083    1.03   0.1    0.739  1.16      0.615 #> 6 C                     2009 1     0.14     1.16  NA     NA     NA        NA     #> 7 C                     2010 0.926 0.158    1.1    0.085  0.877  1.23      0.854 #> 8 C                     2011 0.96  0.112    1.08   0.075  0.872  1.16      0.861 #> 9 C                     2012 0.924 0.133    1.07   0.072  0.875  1.15      0.808 #> # ℹ 4 more variables: mean_sim_survival <dbl>, mean_sim_recruitment <dbl>, #> #   mean_sim_growth <dbl>, median_sim_growth <dbl> bbr_plot_growth(growth_est) bbr_plot_growth_distributions(growth_est)

title: Estimate Calf-Cow Ratio. — bbr_calf_cow_ratio
text: Estimate Calf-Cow Ratio.

title: Estimate Calf-Cow Ratio. — bbr_calf_cow_ratio
code: bbr_calf_cow_ratio(   x,   adult_female_proportion = 0.65,   sex_ratio = 0.5,   variance = "bootstrap",   year_start = 4L )

title: Estimate Calf-Cow Ratio. — bbr_calf_cow_ratio
text: return object columns: PopulationName Population name Year Year sampled estimate Calf-Cow ratio estimate lower Confidence limit upper Confidence limit groups Groups sampled female_calves Estimated female calves females Estimated adult females

title: Estimate Calf-Cow Ratio. — bbr_calf_cow_ratio
text: x data frame recruitment data. adult_female_proportion Assumed estimated proportion females population used assign unknown sex caribou. Values must 0 1. Can set 0 exclude unknown sex caribou recruitment estimates. default set 0.65. sex_ratio Sex ratio caribou birth used assign calves yearlings male female.  Sex ratio defined proportion females birth. Values must 0 1. default set 0.5. variance Estimate variance using "binomial" "bootstrap". default set "bootstrap". year_start whole number 1 12 indicating month start caribou (.e., biological) year. default, April set start caribou year.

title: Estimate Calf-Cow Ratio. — bbr_calf_cow_ratio
text: data frame. columns listed format section.

title: Estimate Calf-Cow Ratio. — bbr_calf_cow_ratio
text: x needs formatted certain manner. confirm input data frame right format can use bbd_chk_data_recruitment function.  See vignette("methods", package = "bbouretro") equations used function. User’s can input assumed proportion females population (estimate females adult caribou unknown sex) well sex ratio birth.

title: Estimate Calf-Cow Ratio. — bbr_calf_cow_ratio
code: calfcow_est <- bbr_calf_cow_ratio(   bboudata::bbourecruit_a,   adult_female_proportion = 0.65,   sex_ratio = 0.5,   variance = "binomial" ) calfcow_est <- bbr_calf_cow_ratio(   bboudata::bbourecruit_a,   adult_female_proportion = 0.60,   sex_ratio = 0.65,   variance = "bootstrap" )

what: Calf Cow Ratio to Recruitment — bbr_cc_to_rec
title: Calf Cow Ratio to Recruitment — bbr_cc_to_rec
text: calf cow ratios simply number calves divided number cows. described DeCesare et al. (2012) order convert calf cow ratio female recruitment rate necessary multiple calf cow ratio sex ratio get female calf cow ratio divide number plus 1 get female recruitment rate ie female calves divided females. perform inverse conversion see bbr_rec_to_cc()

title: Calf Cow Ratio to Recruitment — bbr_cc_to_rec
Calf Cow Ratio to Recruitment — bbr_cc_to_rec
text: x numeric vector calf:cow ratio sex_ratio

title: Calf Cow Ratio to Recruitment — bbr_cc_to_rec
text: numeric vector equivalent recruitment rate

title: Calf Cow Ratio to Recruitment — bbr_cc_to_rec
Simulate population growth — bbr_growth
text: function uses output bbr_survival() bbr_recruitment() estimate population growth (\(\lambda\)) using Hatter-Bergerud equation (Hatter Bergerud, 1991). Monte Carlo simulation used generate confidence limits.

title: Simulate population growth — bbr_growth
text: survival data frame generated bbr_survival(). recruitment data frame generated bbr_recruitment().

title: Simulate population growth — bbr_growth
text: data.frame.

title: Simulate population growth — bbr_growth
text: See vignette("methods", package = "bbouretro") descriptions equations used. raw_values can plotted using bbr_plot_growth_distributions() summary data frame can output using bbr_growth_summarize() plotted using bbr_plot_growth().

title: Simulate population growth — bbr_growth
text: Hatter, Ian, Wendy Bergerud. 1991. “Moose Recruitment, Adult Mortality Rate Change” 27: 65–73.

title: Simulate population growth — bbr_growth
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ recruitment_est <- bbr_recruitment(bboudata::bbourecruit_a) survival_est <- bbr_survival(bboudata::bbousurv_a)  growth_est <- bbr_growth(survival_est, recruitment_est) } # }

title: Summarize population growth — bbr_growth_summarize
text: Provides summary yearly population growth (\(\lambda\)) estimates simulations.

title: Summarize population growth — bbr_growth_summarize
text: return object columns: PopulationName Population name Year Year sampled S Estimated survival R Estimated recruitment estimate Estimated population growth (lambda) se SE lower Percentile 95% confidence limits upper Percentile 95% confidence limits prop_lgt1 Proportion simulations lambda>1 mean_sim_survival Mean simulated survival value mean_sim_recruitment Mean simulated recruitment value mean_sim_growth Mean simulated population growth (lambda) value median_sim_growth Median simulated population growth (lambda) value

title: Summarize population growth — bbr_growth_summarize
text: growth data frame generated bbr_growth().

title: Summarize population growth — bbr_growth_summarize
text: data frame. columns listed format section.

code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ recruitment_est <- bbr_recruitment(bboudata::bbourecruit_a) survival_est <- bbr_survival(bboudata::bbousurv_a) growth_est <- bbr_growth(survival_est, recruitment_est)  bbr_growth_summarize(growth_est) } # }

title: Plot population growth distributions — bbr_plot_growth_distributions
text: Plots generated show distribution simulated population growth (\(\lambda\)) values, mean estimate (red line).  addition, hashed line indicates \(\lambda = 1\).  Plots allow users evaluate symmetry distributions \(\lambda\).

Estimate recruitment — bbr_recruitment
text: Estimate recruitment using DeCesare et al. (2012) methods.

title: Estimate recruitment — bbr_recruitment
code: bbr_recruitment(   x,   adult_female_proportion = 0.65,   sex_ratio = 0.5,   variance = "bootstrap",   year_start = 4L )

title: Estimate recruitment — bbr_recruitment
text: return object columns: PopulationName Population name Year Year sampled estimate Recruitment estimate se SE lower Confidence limit upper Confidence limit groups Groups sampled female_calves Estimated female calves females Estimated adult females

title: Estimate recruitment — bbr_recruitment
text: x data frame recruitment data. adult_female_proportion Assumed estimated proportion females population used assign unknown sex caribou. Values must 0 1. Can set 0 exclude unknown sex caribou recruitment estimates. default set 0.65. sex_ratio Sex ratio caribou birth used assign calves yearlings male female.  Sex ratio defined proportion females birth. Values must 0 1. default set 0.5. variance Estimate variance using "binomial" "bootstrap". default set "bootstrap". year_start whole number 1 12 indicating month start caribou (.e., biological) year. default, April set start caribou year.

title: Estimate recruitment — bbr_recruitment
text: data frame. columns listed format section.

title: Estimate recruitment — bbr_recruitment
text: x needs formatted certain manner. confirm input data frame right format can use bbd_chk_data_recruitment function.  See vignette("methods", package = "bbouretro") equations used function. User’s can input assumed proportion females population (estimate females adult caribou unknown sex) well sex ratio birth.

title: Estimate recruitment — bbr_recruitment
text: DeCesare, Nicholas J., Mark Hebblewhite, Mark Bradley, Kirby G. Smith, David Hervieux, Lalenia Neufeld. 2012 “Estimating Ungulate Recruitment Growth Rates Using Age Ratios.” Journal Wildlife Management 76 (1): 144–53 https://doi.org/10.1002/jwmg.244.

title: Estimate recruitment — bbr_recruitment
code: recruitment_est <- bbr_recruitment(   bboudata::bbourecruit_a,   adult_female_proportion = 0.65,   sex_ratio = 0.5,   variance = "binomial" ) recruitment_est <- bbr_recruitment(   bboudata::bbourecruit_a,   adult_female_proportion = 0.60,   sex_ratio = 0.65,   variance = "bootstrap" )

title: Estimate survival — bbr_survival
text: Estimate survival rates based Kaplan-Meier survival rate estimator (Pollock et al. 1989).

title: Estimate survival — bbr_survival
code: bbr_survival(   x,   include_uncertain_morts = TRUE,   variance = "greenwood",   year_start = 4L )

title: Estimate survival — bbr_survival
text: return object columns: PopulationName Population name Year Year sampled estimate Survival estimate se SE lower Confidence limit upper Confidence limit mean_monitored Mean number caribou monitored month sum_dead Total number mortalities year sum_alive Total number caribou-months year status Indicates less 12 months monitored 0 mortalities given year

title: Estimate survival — bbr_survival
text: x data frame survival data. include_uncertain_morts flag indicating whether include uncertain mortalities total mortalities. default value TRUE. variance Variance type estimate. Can Greenwood estimator "greenwood" Cox Oakes estimator "cox_oakes". default "greenwood". year_start whole number 1 12 indicating month start caribou (.e., biological) year. default, April set start caribou year.

title: Estimate survival — bbr_survival
text: data frame. columns listed format section.

title: Estimate survival — bbr_survival
text: x needs formatted certain manner. confirm input data frame right format can use bbd_chk_data_survival function. See vignette("methods", package = "bbouretro") equations used function.

title: Estimate survival — bbr_survival
text: Pollock, K. H., S. R. Winterstein, C. M. Bunck, P. D. Curtis. 1989. Survival analysis telemetry studies: staggered entry design. Journal Wildlife Management 53:7-15.

title: Estimate survival — bbr_survival
code: survival_est <- bbr_survival(   bboudata::bbousurv_a,   include_uncertain_morts = TRUE,   variance = "greenwood" ) survival_est <- bbr_survival(   bboudata::bbousurv_b,   include_uncertain_morts = FALSE,   variance = "cox_oakes" )
